tn.text: Moses begins to bless the tribes of Israel. Moses speaks the blessing in the form of short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Yahweh came from Sinai and rose from Seir upon them. He shined out from Mount Paran
tn.text: Moses compares Yahweh to the rising sun. AT: "When Yahweh came from Sinai, he looked to them like the sun when it rises from Seir and shines out from Mount Paran" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"upon the people of Israel"
"10,000 angels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: In his right hand were flashes of lightning
tn.text: Other possible meanings are 1) "In his right hand were flames of fire" or 2) "He gave them a law of fire" or 3) "He came from the south, down his mountain slopes."

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:01|33:2]]; Moses speaks the blessing in the form of short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
These verses are difficult to understand.
"the people of Israel"

tn.ref: all his holy ones are in your hand ... your feet ... your words
tn.text: The pronouns "his" and "your" refer to Yahweh. AT: "all Yahweh's holy ones are in his hand ... his feet ... his words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])

tn.ref: all his holy ones are in your hand
tn.text: The hand is a metonym for power and protection. AT: "you protect all his holy people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"a possession" or "a precious possession"
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:01|33:2]]; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Verse 5 is difficult to understand.
"Yahweh became king" (UDB)
This is another name for Israel. Translated as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:32:15|32:15]].
This begins Moses' blessings to the individual tribes of Israel.

tn.ref: but may his men be few
tn.text: Other possible meanings are 1) "and may his men not be few" or 2) "even though his men are few."
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:01|33:2]]; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "voice of Judah" refers to the cries and prayers of the people of Judah. AT: "when the people of Judah pray to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The abstract noun "help" can be translated as a verb. AT: "help him to fight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:01|33:2]]; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

These were sacred stones the high priest carried on his breastplate and used at times to determine God's will. Here "your" refers to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"your holy one" or "the one who seeks to please you." This refers to the tribe of Levi.
Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:06:16|6:16]]. Translator may add a footnote that says: "The name 'Massah' means 'testing.'"
Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:32:50|32:51]]. Translator may add a footnote that says: "The name 'Meribah' means 'argue' or 'quarrel.'"

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:01|33:2]]; the blessings are short poems. He continues describing the tribe of Levi, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:08|33:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "word" refers to the commands of Yahweh. AT: "for they obeyed your commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

These words both mean to watch over and to protect. They are often metaphors for "obeyed," but here they should be translated literally because they refer to a time when the Levites literally killed people who were rebelling against Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He continues to describe the tribe of Levi, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:08|33:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Moses is speaking to Yahweh, so all these words are singular.

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He continues describing the tribe of Levi, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:08|33:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"be pleased with" or "be pleased to accept"
Here the word "hands" refers to the whole person. AT: "all the work that he does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The loins were considered the center of strength. AT: "Take away the strength of" or "Utterly destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This phrase is used twice as a metaphor. AT: "rise up to fight ... cause any more trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is an idiom. AT: "fight against" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: The one loved by Yahweh lives
tn.text: Here Moses is referring to the members of the tribe of Benjamin. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The ones whom Yahweh loves live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The abstact noun "security" can be translated using a verb phrase. AT: "lives where no one can harm him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh protects the tribe of Benjamin with his power or 2) Yahweh lives in the hill region of the tribe of Benjamin. In both translations, it means Yahweh takes care of them.
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This refers to the tribe of Ephraim and the tribe of Manasseh. Both tribes descended from Joseph.

tn.ref: May his land be blessed by Yahweh
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May Yahweh bless their land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: with the precious things of heaven, with the dew
tn.text: "with the precious dew from the sky" or "with the precious rain from the sky"
water that forms on leaves and grass on cool mornings. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:32:01|32:2]].
This refers to the water under the ground.

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He continues to describe the tribe of Joseph, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:13|33:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "May Yahweh bless his land." Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:13|33:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: with the precious things of the harvest of the sun
tn.text: "with the best crops that the sun causes to grow"

tn.ref: with the precious things of the produce of the months
tn.text: "with the best crops that grow month to month"
Moses is probably referring to food crops. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "the best fruits ... the precious fruits" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the mountains that existed long ago"
"the hills that will exist forever"

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He continues to describe the tribe of Joseph, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:13|33:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "May Yahweh bless his land." Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:13|33:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The abstract noun "abundance" can be translated as a verb phrase. AT: "what it produces in large amounts"

tn.ref: him who was in the bush
tn.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "Yahweh, who spoke to Moses from the burning bush" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Let the blessing come on the head of Joseph
tn.text: This metaphor is of a man putting his hand on the head of a son and asking God to bless the son. The man here is Yahweh. AT: "May Yahweh bless Joseph as a father blesses his son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: come on the head of Joseph, and on the top of the head of him
tn.text: Here "head" and "top of the head" refer to the whole person and are a reference to Joseph's descendants. AT: "be upon the descendants of Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Another possible meaning is "brow" or "forehead."

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He continues to describe the tribe of Joseph, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:13|33:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: The firstborn of an ox, majestic is he
tn.text: The ox is a metaphor for something large and strong. The word "firstborn" is a metaphor for honor. AT: "People will honor Joseph's descendants, who are many and powerful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: his horns are the horns of
tn.text: The horn is a metaphor for strength. AT: "he is as strong as" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Pushing with his horns is a metaphor for strength. AT: "He is so strong that he will push" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: ten thousands of Ephraim ... the thousands of Manasseh
tn.text: This means the tribe of Ephraim will be stronger than the tribe of Manasseh. AT: "the people of Ephraim, who number many times 10,000 ... the people of Manasseh, who number many times 1,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

Moses continues to bless each tribe of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He speaks to the tribes of Zebulun and Issachar as if they were one man, so the word "your" and the command "rejoice" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out, and you, Issachar, in your tents
tn.text: The people of Zebulun were located near the Mediterranean Sea. They traveled by sea and traded with other people. The people of Issachar preferred peaceful living and working the land and raising cattle. You can make clear the understood information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"It is there that they will offer"
"acceptable sacrifices" or "proper sacrifices"

tn.ref: For they will suck the abundance of the seas, and from the sand on the seashore
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) they will trade with people across the sea or 2) they were beginning to use sand in making pottery.

tn.ref: For they will suck the abundance of the seas
tn.text: The Hebrew word translated "suck" here refers to how a baby nurses at its mother's breast. It means the people will gain wealth from the sea like a baby gets milk from its mother. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Blessed be he who enlarges Gad
tn.text: This can stated in active form. AT: Possible meanings are 1) "May Yahweh bless Gad and give him much land to live in" or 2) "People should say that Yahweh is good because he has given Gad much land to live in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: He will live there like a lioness, and he will tear off an arm or a head
tn.text: This means the people of Gad are strong and secure, and they will defeat their enemies in war. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He continues to describe the tribe of Gad as one man, which he began to do in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:33:20|33:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This means a larger piece of land that a leader normally took.

tn.ref: He came with the heads of the people
tn.text: "They met with all the leaders of the Israelites"

tn.ref: He carried out the justice of Yahweh and his decrees with Israel
tn.text: "They obeyed all that Yahweh had commanded the Israelites"
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Dan is a lion cub that leaps out from Bashan
tn.text: The people of Dan are strong like a lion cub, and they attack their enemies who live in Bashan. You can make clear the understood information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. He speaks of the descendants  of Naphtali as if they were one man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

Yahweh being pleased with Naphtali is spoken of as if "favor" were food that Naphtali ate until he was no longer hungry. AT: "who has all the good things he desires because Yahweh is pleased with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: full of the blessing of Yahweh
tn.text: Blessings are spoken of as if they were food that Naphtali ate until he could hold no more. AT: "whom Yahweh has blessed so that he has all he needs"
Moses speaks as if the tribe of Naphtali is one man, so these words are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: the land to the west and south
tn.text: This refers to the land around Lake Galilee. The full meaning of this statement may be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Moses continues to bless the tribes of Israel; the blessings are short poems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: dip his foot in olive oil
tn.text: Olive oil was used for food and for the skin of the face and arms. Feet were dirty, so to put the foot in olive oil was to ruin valuable oil. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "have so much olive oil that he can afford to waste it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: your city bars ... your days ... your security
tn.text: Moses speaks to the tribe of Asher as if they are one man, so all instances of "your" are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: May your city bars be iron and bronze
tn.text: Cities had large bars across their gates to keep enemies out. The meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "May you be safe from attacks by your enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is another name for the people of Israel. It means "upright one." Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:32:15|32:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: rides through the heavens ... on the clouds
tn.text: This is an image of Yahweh riding on clouds through the sky like a king on his chariot riding through a battlefield. AT: "rides through the heavens like a king rides through a battlefield ... on the clouds like a king on his chariot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"to help you." Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the word "you" here is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: The eternal God is a refuge
tn.text: The abstract noun "refuge," which means a shelter or a place safe from danger, can be stated as a verb. AT: "The eternal God will protect his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

The words "everlasting arms" are a metaphor for Yahweh's promise to protect his people forever. AT: "he will support and take care of his people forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Moses speaks of the future as if it were the past to emphasize that what he is saying will come true. AT "He will thrust out ... he will say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the word "you" and the command "destroy" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
If this direct quotation would not work well in your language, you may change it to an indirect quotation. AT: "he will tell you to destroy them!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: Israel dwelt ... Jacob's spring was secure
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Moses speaks of the future as if it were the past to emphasize that what he is saying will come true, "Israel will dwell ... Jacob's spring will be secure" or 2) Moses is blessing Israel, "May Israel dwell ... and may Jacob's spring be secure." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
Possible meanings are 1) Jacob's home or 2) Jacob's descendants. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The dew is spoken of as being so much that it is as if it were raining. Possible meanings are 1) Moses is blessing Israel, "may much dew cover the land like rain" or 2) Moses is telling what will happen in the future, "much dew will cover the land like rain." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
water that forms on leaves and grass on cool mornings. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:32:01|32:2]].
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Who is like you, a people saved by Yahweh ... majesty?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. It can also be stated in active form. AT: "There is no other people group like you, a people whom Yahweh has saved ... majesty." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This merism speaks of Yahweh defending the Israelites from their enemies and enabling them to attack their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

The word "shield" is a metaphor for Yahweh protecting and defending the Israelites. The abstract noun "help" can be translated as a verb. AT: "the one who protects you and helps you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

The word "sword" is a metaphor for the power to kill with the sword in order to win battles. AT: "the one who enables you to win battles and so have majesty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will trample down their high places
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the Israelites will destroy the places where the other people worship false gods or 2) the Israelites will walk on the backs of their enemies when the Israelites defeat them.
